citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult female cocker spaniel (microchip # 933000320864621) was observed with a cloudy cornea in the left eye in
enclosure # 10, in room # 5. The third eyelid appeared red and swollen. There was yellow discharge with shavings
adhering to the hair around the eye.
An adult female Yorkie (microchip # 933000320543428) was observed with a cloudy cornea in the left eye in enclosure #
5, in room # 5. There was a crusted discharge with shavings adhering to the hair around the eye. The Yorkie was noted to
be squinting while the inspector examined her eye. Squinting can be a sign that the eye condition was painful.
There were no recent observations or treatments recorded for these two dogs prior to the inspection on April 16, 2024.
APHIS inspector requested during the inspection that the licensee have these two dogs examined by the attending
veterinarian. Both dogs were examined by the attending veterinarian on April 17, 2024, and are under treatment.
Inadequate daily observations to identify sick or injured animals can result in conditions becoming worse. Failure of the
licensee to identify medical problems in dogs and communicate these to the attending veterinarian can result in prolonged
suffering in animals. The licensee must follow all recommendations for treatment by the attending veterinarian.
Documentation of examinations and treatments must be maintained for future review by APHIS officials. Correct by April
18, 2024.

An adult male jug (Jack Russell terrier & pug mix) was observed jumping on the tops of partitions and into an adjacent
enclosure housing two dogs in room # 4. Dogs jumping and entering other enclosures can cause fights among the other
dogs or be injured trying to jump on and over partitions. Licensee must ensure that enclosures are constructed and
maintained to keep the dogs contained to prevent injury. Correct by April 22, 2024.
This inspection was conducted with the licensee on April 16, 2024, and the exit interview was conducted with the facility
representative on April 18, 2024.
Additional Inspectors:
Catherine Beckwith, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist
Jeffrey Shepherd, Assistant Director n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult female cocker spaniel (microchip # 933000320864621) was observed with a cloudy cornea in the left eye in 
enclosure # 10, in room # 5. The third eyelid appeared red and swollen. There was yellow discharge with shavings 
adhering to the hair around the eye. 
 
An adult female Yorkie (microchip # 933000320543428) was observed with a cloudy cornea in the left eye in enclosure # 
5, in room # 5. There was a crusted discharge with shavings adhering to the hair around the eye. The Yorkie was noted to 
be squinting while the inspector examined her eye. Squinting can be a sign that the eye condition was painful. 
 
There were no recent observations or treatments recorded for these two dogs prior to the inspection on April 16, 2024. 
APHIS inspector requested during the inspection that the licensee have these two dogs examined by the attending 
veterinarian. Both dogs were examined by the attending veterinarian on April 17, 2024, and are under treatment. 
 
Inadequate daily observations to identify sick or injured animals can result in conditions becoming worse. Failure of the 
licensee to identify medical problems in dogs and communicate these to the attending veterinarian can result in prolonged 
suffering in animals. The licensee must follow all recommendations for treatment by the attending veterinarian. 
Documentation of examinations and treatments must be maintained for future review by APHIS officials. Correct by April 
18, 2024. 
3.6(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An adult male jug (Jack Russell terrier & pug mix) was observed jumping on the tops of partitions and into an adjacent 
enclosure housing two dogs in room # 4. Dogs jumping and entering other enclosures can cause fights among the other 
dogs or be injured trying to jump on and over partitions. Licensee must ensure that enclosures are constructed and 
maintained to keep the dogs contained to prevent injury. Correct by April 22, 2024. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the licensee on April 16, 2024, and the exit interview was conducted with the facility 
representative on April 18, 2024.

Additional Inspectors: 
Catherine Beckwith, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist 
Jeffrey Shepherd, Assistant Director n
